For over two years, I have been gradually increasing my use of Finnish at work. It has been an adventure, with its ups and downs, as I strive to improve my Finnish for daily use in my job but I am glad to have supportive work environment. English was my initial safety net, but with time, I have increasingly turned to Finnish. Although I feel more comfortable to speak Finnish, there are still moments when joining work-related discussions feels like balancing on a thin rope, forming and organizing my thoughts while actively engaging. This experience has led me to reflect on how we internationals integrate into Finnish-speaking environment and develop fluency: slowly. My message to Finnish organizations and companies: I encourage you to support those who are still learning Finnish by creating a motivating environment for using Finnish at different levels of proficiency. Achieving fluency is a marathon, not a sprint. By providing opportunities to non-native or emerging Finnish speakers, you are not just investing in linguistic diversity but also using a supply of varied experiences and skills. These individuals offer more than just language skills to your team‚Äîthey bring unique insights and diverse viewpoints that could be key to achieving your organization's or company's objectives. #LanguageLearning #WorkplaceDiversity #FinnishLanguage #ProfessionalGrowth

English is a global language that is widely used in business communication across countries, but should all companies enforce their current employees to have good English proficiency? The issue is still controversial until now. In the fourth cultural intelligence session by Dr. Catherine Wu, my classmates and I discussed Englishnization in the Rakuten case. The CEO of the firm mandated their current employees to pass the minimum requirement in TOEIC score (An English Proficiency Test) or to get demoted. When we discussed recommendations for the situation, it reminded me of how my colleagues in my previous company communicated with our foreign suppliers. Unlike most companies in Thailand, my company did not require any English proficiency qualification. Each of us could communicate and cooperate with our overseas suppliers well even though we do not have great English proficiency. From my perspective, I oppose the enforcement of English proficiency as the Rakuten firm did, but I prefer the corporation to create learning environments to help current employees improve their English skills over time. This would allow current employees to work efficiently in usual operations and enjoy learning English to communicate with foreigners. The elaboration is one of the takeaways from the previous session and I hope that I could learn more fascinating topics in the future.
